paragraphs.text:
%md

# Linear classifiers

In the previous notebooks, we have analyzed the dataset and found relevant patters. During this notebook, we will try two very simple machine learning models to see if the features we have explored are enough to represent each enrollment. Linear models cannot process sequences, so we must aggregates all interactions in a vector of fixed size.

msg.data:
Linear classifiers

In the previous notebooks, we have analyzed the dataset and found relevant patters. During this notebook, we will try two very simple machine learning models to see if the features we have explored are enough to represent each enrollment. Linear models cannot process sequences, so we must aggregates all interactions in a vector of fixed size.

val BASE_DATA_DIRNAME = Array(System.getProperty("user.home"),  "tmp", "kddcup15_dataset", "clean").mkString(File.separator)
val SESSIONS_FILENAME = new java.io.File(BASE_DATA_DIRNAME, "sessions.csv").getPath
val LOG_TRAIN_FILENAME = new java.io.File(BASE_DATA_DIRNAME, "log_train.csv").getPath
val ENROLLEMENT_TRAIN_FILENAME = new java.io.File(BASE_DATA_DIRNAME, "enrollment_train.csv").getPath

paragraphs.text:
%md ## 3.2 Dummy baseline

To have an intuition of how hard the task is, it is common to use a simple decision rule as classification. For example, assigning a random label o the most common value. In this case, for all courses we would assign the dropout label. This also corresponds with the scenario of assuming that every student is at risk, and producing interventions for every one of them.

msg.data:
3.2 Dummy baseline

To have an intuition of how hard the task is, it is common to use a simple decision rule as classification. For example, assigning a random label o the most common value. In this case, for all courses we would assign the dropout label. This also corresponds with the scenario of assuming that every student is at risk, and producing interventions for every one of them.

paragraphs.text:
%md

To evaluate the performance of the models, we will use two classification metrics, the area under the ROC curve (AUC) and the accuracy, and two regression metrics: the R2 score and the RMSE score. We can use the evaluators provided by the SparkML library, with the exception of the accuracy which is not implemented. We will create our dummy predictions to fit their expeted input format.

msg.data: To evaluate the performance of the models, we will use two classification metrics, the area under the ROC curve (AUC) and the accuracy, and two regression metrics: the R2 score and the RMSE score. We can use the evaluators provided by the SparkML library, with the exception of the accuracy which is not implemented. We will create our dummy predictions to fit their expeted input format.

paragraphs.text: val dummyPredictions = trainEnrollmentDF.drop("username").withColumn("positiveProb", lit(1.0)).withColumn("probability", lit(1.0)).withColumn("prediction", lit(1))

msg.data: dummyPredictions: org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame = [enrollment_id: int, course_id: int ... 4 more fields]

paragraphs.text:
val evaluatorAUC = new BinaryClassificationEvaluator()
      .setMetricName("areaUnderROC")
      .setRawPredictionCol("probability")
      .setLabelCol("label")

val evaluatorR2 = new RegressionEvaluator().
  setMetricName("r2").
  setPredictionCol("positiveProb").
  setLabelCol("label")
  
val evaluatorRMSE = new RegressionEvaluator().
  setMetricName("rmse").
  setPredictionCol("positiveProb").
  setLabelCol("label")

def accuracy(predictionsDF: DataFrame, labelCol:String, predictionCol:String):Double = {
    predictionsDF.where(col(labelCol) === col(predictionCol)).count() / predictionsDF.count().toFloat
}

%md
## 3.3 Building the represetation

msg.data: 3.3 Building the represetation

paragraphs.text:
%md

Going back to the machine learning classfiers, the first step neccesary to used them is to transform the sequences in the required format. As these classifiers can't process sequential data, we must create a feature vector that represents each enrollment and aggregates the relevant information. Based on the previous analysis, we will use:

* [totalActions] The total number of interactions
* [eventTypeAvg] The average number of interactions per session, divided by type
* [eventTypeCount] The average number of interactions per session, divided by type
* [totalSessions] The number of different sessions
* [durationAvg] The average duration of sessions
* [sessionsAvgActionCount] The average actions per session

msg.data:
Going back to the machine learning classfiers, the first step neccesary to used them is to transform the sequences in the required format. As these classifiers can’t process sequential data, we must create a feature vector that represents each enrollment and aggregates the relevant information. Based on the previous analysis, we will use:

  • [totalActions] The total number of interactions
  • [eventTypeAvg] The average number of interactions per session, divided by type
  • [eventTypeCount] The average number of interactions per session, divided by type
  • [totalSessions] The number of different sessions
  • [durationAvg] The average duration of sessions
  • [sessionsAvgActionCount] The average actions per session

paragraphs.text:
val sessionFeatures = aggSessions
    .select("totalActions", "enrollment_id", "access", "wiki", "navigate", "discussion", "problem", "video", "page_close", "duration")
    .groupBy("enrollment_id").agg(
        sum("totalActions").alias("totalActions"),
        mean("totalActions").alias("sessionsAvgActionCount"),
        count(lit(1)).alias("totalSessions"),
        mean("duration").alias("durationAvg"),
        mean("access").alias("accessAvg"), 
        mean("wiki").alias("wikiAvg"), 
        mean("navigate").alias("navigateAvg"), 
        mean("discussion").alias("discussionAvg"), 
        mean("problem").alias("problemAvg"), 
        mean("video").alias("videoAvg"), 
        mean("page_close").alias("page_closeAvg"),
        sum("access").alias("accessCount"), 
        sum("wiki").alias("wikiCount"), 
        sum("navigate").alias("navigateCount"), 
        sum("discussion").alias("discussionCount"), 
        sum("problem").alias("problemCount"), 
        sum("video").alias("videoCount"), 
        sum("page_close").alias("page_closeCount")
).na.fill(0.0)

sessionFeatures.show(4)
%md We need to train a different model for each course. As we are doing a proof of concept and do not look for hyperparameter optimization, we will use the default settings.

msg.data: We need to train a different model for each course. As we are doing a proof of concept and do not look for hyperparameter optimization, we will use the default settings.

val trainLogsDF = sqlContext.read.format("csv").option("header", "true").option("inferSchema", "true").load(LOG_TRAIN_FILENAME).join(
    trainEnrollmentDF.select($"enrollment_id", $"course_id".cast("int")), "enrollment_id")

paragraphs.text: %md ## 3.4 Linear regression

msg.data: 3.4 Linear regression

paragraphs.text:
val featureColumns = Array(
    "sessionsAvgActionCount", "totalSessions", "durationAvg", "accessAvg", "wikiAvg", "navigateAvg",
    "discussionAvg", "problemAvg", "videoAvg", "page_closeAvg", "accessCount", "wikiCount",
    "navigateCount", "discussionCount", "problemCount", "videoCount", "page_closeCount", "totalActions")

val mlDataset = trainEnrollmentDF.drop("username")
    .join(sessionFeatures, Seq("enrollment_id"))

msg.data:
featureColumns: Array[String] = Array(sessionsAvgActionCount, totalSessions, durationAvg, accessAvg, wikiAvg, navigateAvg, discussionAvg, problemAvg, videoAvg, page_closeAvg, accessCount, wikiCount, navigateCount, discussionCount, problemCount, videoCount, page_closeCount, totalActions)
mlDataset: org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame = [enrollment_id: int, course_id: int ... 19 more fields]

paragraphs.text:
// We need a custom function to extract the probability of the positive class
val probExtractor = udf {
    (x: Any) => {
      val el = x.getClass.getDeclaredMethod("toArray").invoke(x)
      val array = el.asInstanceOf[Array[Double]]
      array(1)
    }
}

// Train a LR classifier on data from the given course
// Returns the test AUC, the train AUC and the array of test predictions
def trainOnCourse(course:Int): (Double, Double, DataFrame, Int) = {

    val Array(trainDataset, testDataset) = mlDataset.where($"course_id" === lit(course)).randomSplit(Array(0.8, 0.2), seed = 42)

    val assembler = new VectorAssembler()
      .setInputCols(featureColumns)
      .setOutputCol("features")

    // TODO scale features!
    val scaler = new StandardScaler()
       .setInputCol("features")
       .setOutputCol("scaledFeatures")
       .setWithStd(true)
       .setWithMean(false)

    val lr = new LogisticRegression()
      .setMaxIter(20)
      .setRegParam(0.001)
  
    val pipeline = new Pipeline()
      .setStages(Array(assembler, lr))
  
    // Fit the pipeline to training documents.
    val model = pipeline.fit(trainDataset)

    val testPredictions = model.transform(testDataset).select("label", "probability", "prediction").withColumn("positiveProb", probExtractor($"probability"))
    val trainPredictions = model.transform(trainDataset).select("label", "probability")
    
    val evaluator = new BinaryClassificationEvaluator()
      .setMetricName("areaUnderROC")
      .setRawPredictionCol("probability")
      .setLabelCol("label")
     
    testPredictions
        .select("label", "positiveProb").write
        .mode(SaveMode.Overwrite)
        .option("header", "true")
        .parquet(new java.io.File(BASE_DATA_DIRNAME, "lr_predictions_c" + course.toString + ".parquet").getPath)

    return (evaluator.evaluate(testPredictions), evaluator.evaluate(trainPredictions), testPredictions, course)
}

msg.data:
probExtractor: org.apache.spark.sql.expressions.UserDefinedFunction = UserDefinedFunction(<function1>,DoubleType,None)
trainOnCourse: (course: Int)(Double, Double, org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame, Int)

paragraphs.text:
val results = List.range(0, 39).map(trainOnCourse)
val allPredictions = results.map(t => t._3).reduce(_.union(_))
allPredictions.cache()
val performances = results.map(t => (t._1, t._2, t._4)).toDF("testAUC", "trainAUC", "course_id")

// If you loose for some reason the predictions, they can be recovered with this function.

def prediction_file(course:Int): DataFrame = {
    val filename = new java.io.File(
        BASE_DATA_DIRNAME, "lr_predictions_c" + course.toString + ".parquet").getPath
    return sqlContext.read.option("header", "true").option("inferSchema", "true").parquet(filename)
}

val predictions = List.range(0, 39).map(prediction_file(_))

val probAssembler = new VectorAssembler()
    .setInputCols(Array("negativeProb", "positiveProb"))
    .setOutputCol("probability")

val allPredictions = probAssembler.transform(predictions
    .reduce(_.union(_))
    .withColumn("prediction", ($"positiveProb" > lit(0.5)).cast("Int"))
    .withColumn("negativeProb", lit(1) - $"positiveProb"))

allPredictions.show(4)

// We need a custom function to extract the probability of the positive class

// Train a LR classifier on data from the given course
// Returns the test AUC, the train AUC and the array of test predictions
def trainOnCourse(course:Int): (Double, Double, DataFrame, Int) = {

    val Array(trainDataset, testDataset) = mlDataset.where($"course_id" === lit(course)).randomSplit(Array(0.8, 0.2), seed = 42)

    val assembler = new VectorAssembler()
      .setInputCols(featureColumnsNoSess)
      .setOutputCol("features")

    // TODO scale features!
    val scaler = new StandardScaler()
       .setInputCol("features")
       .setOutputCol("scaledFeatures")
       .setWithStd(true)
       .setWithMean(false)

    val lr = new LogisticRegression()
      .setMaxIter(20)
      .setRegParam(0.001)
  
    val pipeline = new Pipeline()
      .setStages(Array(assembler, lr))
  
    // Fit the pipeline to training documents.
    val model = pipeline.fit(trainDataset)

    val testPredictions = model.transform(testDataset).select("label", "probability", "prediction").withColumn("positiveProb", probExtractor($"probability"))
    val trainPredictions = model.transform(trainDataset).select("label", "probability")
    
    val evaluator = new BinaryClassificationEvaluator()
      .setMetricName("areaUnderROC")
      .setRawPredictionCol("probability")
      .setLabelCol("label")
     
    testPredictions
        .select("label", "positiveProb").write
        .mode(SaveMode.Overwrite)
        .option("header", "true")
        .parquet(new java.io.File(BASE_DATA_DIRNAME, "lr_predictions_no_sess_c" + course.toString + ".parquet").getPath)

    return (evaluator.evaluate(testPredictions), evaluator.evaluate(trainPredictions), testPredictions, course)
}

paragraphs.text:
%md

## 3.5 Decision Trees

msg.data: 3.5 Decision Trees

paragraphs.text:
// We need a custom function to extract the probability of the positive class
val probExtractor = udf {
    (x: Any) => {
      val el = x.getClass.getDeclaredMethod("toArray").invoke(x)
      val array = el.asInstanceOf[Array[Double]]
      array(1)
    }
}

// Train a Decision Tree classifier on data from the given course
// Returns the test AUC, the train AUC, the array of test predictions and the string
// description of the classifier
def trainDTOnCourse(course:Int): (Double, Double, DataFrame, Int, String) = {

    val Array(trainDataset, testDataset) = mlDataset.where($"course_id" === lit(course)).randomSplit(Array(0.8, 0.2), seed = 42)

    val assembler = new VectorAssembler()
      .setInputCols(featureColumns)
      .setOutputCol("features")

    // TODO scale features!
    val scaler = new StandardScaler()
       .setInputCol("features")
       .setOutputCol("scaledFeatures")
       .setWithStd(true)
       .setWithMean(false)

    val dt = new DecisionTreeClassifier()
      .setMaxDepth(5)
      .setMinInstancesPerNode(20)
  
    val pipeline = new Pipeline()
      .setStages(Array(assembler, dt))
  
    // Fit the pipeline to training documents.
    val model = pipeline.fit(trainDataset)

    val testPredictions = model.transform(testDataset).select("label", "probability", "prediction").withColumn("positiveProb", probExtractor($"probability"))
    val trainPredictions = model.transform(trainDataset).select("label", "probability")
    
    val evaluator = new BinaryClassificationEvaluator()
      .setMetricName("areaUnderROC")
      .setRawPredictionCol("probability")
      .setLabelCol("label")
    
    val strDescription = model.stages.last
        .asInstanceOf[org.apache.spark.ml.classification.DecisionTreeClassificationModel].toDebugString
     
    testPredictions
        .select("label", "positiveProb").write
        .mode(SaveMode.Overwrite)
        .option("header", "true")
        .parquet(new java.io.File(BASE_DATA_DIRNAME, "dt_predictions_c" + course.toString + ".parquet").getPath)

    return (evaluator.evaluate(testPredictions), evaluator.evaluate(trainPredictions), testPredictions, course, strDescription)
}

msg.data:
probExtractor: org.apache.spark.sql.expressions.UserDefinedFunction = UserDefinedFunction(<function1>,DoubleType,None)
trainDTOnCourse: (course: Int)(Double, Double, org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame, Int, String)

paragraphs.text:
val resultsDT = List.range(0, 39).map(trainDTOnCourse)
val allPredictionsDT = resultsDT.map(t => t._3).reduce(_.union(_))
allPredictionsDT.cache()
val performancesDT = resultsDT.map(t => (t._1, t._2, t._4)).toDF("testAUC", "trainAUC", "course_id")
val descriptionsDT = resultsDT.map(t => (t._4, t._5)).toDF("course_id", "desc_string")

paragraphs.text:
val LRPerformances = sqlContext.read
    .option("header", "true").option("inferSchema", "true")
    .parquet(new java.io.File(BASE_DATA_DIRNAME, "lr_performances.parquet").getPath)
    .withColumn("Model", lit("LR"))
    
val LRNoSessPerformance = sqlContext.read
    .option("header", "true").option("inferSchema", "true")
    .parquet(new java.io.File(BASE_DATA_DIRNAME, "lr_performances_no_sess.parquet").getPath)
    .withColumn("Model", lit("LR + session"))
    
val DTPerformances = sqlContext.read
    .option("header", "true").option("inferSchema", "true")
    .parquet(new java.io.File(BASE_DATA_DIRNAME, "dt_performances.parquet").getPath)
    .withColumn("Model", lit("DT"))
    
val performances = LRPerformances.union(LRNoSessPerformance.union(DTPerformances))
performances.registerTempTable("performances")

%pyspark
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn

# colors used for visualizations
dark_blue = '#473198'
light_blue = '#cce6f4'
purple = '#7d5ba6'
light_green = '#acfcd9ff'
red = '#ff5d5d'
dark_green = '#00ff91'

model_palette = {'LR': purple, 'LR + session': dark_green, 'DT': red}

seaborn.set_style('whitegrid')
seaborn.set_context('paper', font_scale=2)

%pyspark
performances = sqlContext.table('performances').toPandas()
seaborn.catplot(data=performances, x='course_id', y='testAUC', kind='point', hue='Model',
                palette=model_palette, aspect=4);

msg.data: <seaborn.axisgrid.FacetGrid object at 0x7effc91fb518>

paragraphs.text:
%md

We observe the classifier performance decreases with the course size. For the first courses, 0 to 5, there is no variance between the classifiers. However, from many of the other courses, wich has less sequences, the difference is more significant. With the exception of courses 25, 26 and 27, the Logistic Regression obtains better results than the Decision Tree. To summarize this results in a more concise visualization, we will group the courses according to their size. From the visualizations obtained in the first notebook, we select the follwing categories: 5 big courses with more than 6000 training students, 9 medium courses with between 5000 and 2000 students and 24 small courses with less than 2000 students. We plot the distribution obtained by each type of model according to these categories.

From the visualizations obtained in the first notebook, we select the follwing categories: 5 big courses with more than 6000 training students, 9 medium courses with between 5000 and 2000 students and 24 small courses with less than 2000 students. We plot the distribution obtained by each type of model according to these categories.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

seaborn.catplot(data=performances_by_size, x='CourseSize', y='testAUC', kind='boxen',
                hue='Model', palette=model_palette, aspect=1.5)
plt.xlabel('Course size')
plt.ylabel('AUC')

%md

In the figure, we can see the difference between the LR classifier with and without session information is only relevant when courses are small, obtaining very similar results in the other cases. Likewise, the Decision Trees are not achieving good results for small courses, where the classification is more difficult and there is fewer data to build reliable decision rules.

Using the D3 library for javascript, we will visualize the decisions used by the classifier to asign a particular label. The code is taken from https://github.com/tristaneljed/Decision-Tree-Visualization-Spark and modified for this notebook.
